The company now wishes to launch a new range of connected toys, ones that can talk and interact 
with children. The CEO of the company is touting these toys as the next big thing due to the increased 
possibilities offered: The figures can answer children's questions on various subjects, such as 
mathematical calculations or the weather. Each figure is equipped with a microphone and speaker and 
can connect to any smartphone or tablet via Bluetooth. Any mobile device within a 10-meter radius 
can connect to the toys via Bluetooth as well. The figures can also be associated with other figures 
(from the same manufacturer) and interact with each other for an enhanced play experience. 
When a child asks the toy a question, the request is sent to the cloud for analysis, and the answer is 
generated on cloud servers and sent back to the figure. The answer is given through the figure's 
integrated speakers making it appear as though the toy is actually responding to the child's question. 
The packaging of the toy does not provide technical details on how this works, nor does it mention 
that this feature requires an internet connection. The necessary data processing for this has been 
outsourced to a data centre located in South Africa. However, your company has not yet revised its 
consumer-facing privacy policy to indicate this. 
In parallel, the company is planning to introduce a new range of game systems through which 
consumers can play the characters they acquire in the course of playing the game. The system will 
come bundled with a portal that includes a near-field communications (NFC) reader. This device will 
read an RFID tag in the action figure, making the figure come to life onscreen. Each character has its 
own stock features and abilities, but it is also possible to earn additional ones by accomplishing game 
goals. The only information stored in the tag relates to the figures' abilities. It is easy to switch 
characters during the game, and it is possible to bring the figure to locations outside of the home and 
have the character's abilities remain intact.

question_text: What is the main reason GDPR Article 4(22) establishes the concept of the supervisory authority  concerned?
option_a: To encourage the consistency of local data processing activity.
option_b: To give corporations a choice about who their supervisory authority will be.
option_c: To ensure that the interests of data subjects residing outside the lead authority's jurisdiction  are represented.
option_d: To ensure the GDPR covers controllers that do not have an establishment in the EU but have a  representative in a member state.

question_text: Your companys chief information security officer is performing an annual review of its bring your  own device (BYOD) program for its European subsidiary. She has asked you to validate that the technical teams process document is compliant with GDPR. Which step would result in non-compliance with the GDPR?
option_a: Implementing encryption at rest and in transit to protect personal data.
option_b: Assuring basic security measures, such as device locking with password.
option_c: Allowing access to all apps on the device to monitor for security risks or flaws.
option_d: Controlling remote access by ensuring there are reasonable user authentication protocols.

question_text: Which of the following is TRUE with regard to the provisions of the ePrivacy Directive?
option_a: They set forth the requirements for controllers to obtain consent solely for marketing through  text messaging.
option_b: They require websites to obtain user consent for all cookies, including those necessary for the  site to function.
option_c: They are more specific than the GDPR and therefore data controllers need only comply with the  ePrivacy Directive.
option_d: They do not constitute a binding law on data controllers but are requirements for EU member  states to enact legislation.

question_text: A Brazilian citizen is visiting Paris, France on a one-year work visa. During their time in France,  they join a local health and fitness club. The registration form for the health club requests their full name, permanent home address, bank account information for withdrawal of membership fees, and their race or ethnic origin for statistical purposes. Which information requested is considered a special category of personal data under Article 9 of the GDPR?
option_a: Full name.
option_b: Racial or ethnic origin.
option_c: Bank account information.
option_d: Permanent home address.

question_text: A bakery placed a video surveillance camera in the employee break room. The camera is pointed  in a manner so that it only records the portion of the wall that holds the employee timeclock. The employer setup the camera after some employees were caught clocking in for other employees who were running late to work. The employer reviews the footage weekly and then deletes the footage. A sign is posted next to the timeclock informing employees about the recording. If the employees exercise their right to object, what will the employer need to do to continue the video monitoring?
option_a: The employer must show compelling legitimate grounds that override the rights of the data  subjects.
option_b: The employer may continue as the recordings are on private property within the employee  break room.
option_c: The employer would have to cease video surveillance as the data subjects have withdrawn  consent.
option_d: The employer must show that the processing activity is not likely to result in a high risk to the  rights and freedoms of individuals.

question_text: Under Article 21 of the GDPR, a controller must stop profiling when requested by a data subject  unless the controller can demonstrate compelling legitimate grounds that override the interests of the individual. In the Guidelines on Automated individual decision-making and Profiling, the European Data Protection Board (EDPB) says the controller needs to do all of the following to demonstrate it has such legitimate grounds EXCEPT?
option_a: Consider the importance of the profiling to the controllers particular objectives.
option_b: Consider the impact of the profiling on the data subject's interest, rights and freedoms.
option_c: Demonstrate that the profiling is for the purposes of direct marketing and in the controllers  best interest.
option_d: Carry out an exercise that balances the controllers interest and the basis for the data subject's  objection.

question_text: Under which of the following conditions is a controller in the EU likely to be exempt from having to  inform data subjects of the processing of their personal data under Articles 13 and 14 of the GDPR?
option_a: If the controller purchases the personal data from a third-party seller.
option_b: If the data subject is already aware of the processing of their personal data.
option_c: If the data subject provided the personal information to another third party.
option_d: If the data subject provided the personal data directly to the controller.

scenario_text:
Please use the following scenario to answer the next THREE questions. 
Museum4yourSenses is a new museum with an exceptionally modern feel and is gaining a lot of 
traction on PluckPlack, a popular social media app. To promote their multi-location launch, founders 
aim to go viral with captivating avatar-enhanced videos on PluckPlack. 
The museums unique pitch is a chance for the first 100 visitors of the day to test out new virtual 
reality headsets for free. Visitors first step into a rainbow-colored waiting room where they receive 
instructions to speak their name and introduce the character they wish to become for the day. When 
visitors get their photo taken for their badge, they are instructed to look directly at the camera and 
make a funny face. 
A month before the museum opened in Brussels, a private reception was held. The organisers gave 
visitors forms that included a box to acknowledge having read the museums privacy notice and a 
consent form to sign about the images and voice recordings that would be required for entry. The 
consent form stated the personal data would be deleted 24 hours after the initial visit. After the 
Brussels launch, some of the visitors noticed the museum had posted promotional videos on 
PluckPlack that used the visitors introductory voice recordings. The consent forms did not mention 
that the audio recordings would be combined with new avatars for the museums reuse.
question_text: After visiting the Museum4yourSenses, what would visitors be entitled to request regarding their  personal data?
option_a: That the museum stop using their names and voices via social media channels.
option_b: That the museum cease processing their personal data immediately upon receipt of their  request.
option_c: That a copy of the images and videos created from their introductions be provided for their  own personal social media use.
option_d: That monetary compensation be provided to them based on the number of views received by  each video in which their likeness appears.

Museum4yourSenses deflected any responsibility, stating it was their audio-visual vendor handling the audio recordings of the visitors. Which statement about responsibility for the misuse of the visitors personal data is correct?
option_a: The audio-video vendor is responsible because they used the data in a way that wasnt  consistent with their contract with Museum4yourSenses.
option_b: As the controller, Museum4yourSenses is responsible for the audio-visual vendors processing  of personal data as provided in the contract between the museum and the vendor.
option_c: The audio-visual vendor is not responsible because it has limited its liability in the  Museum4yourSenses privacy notice that visitors acknowledged having read prior to entry.
option_d: Museum4yourSenses is not responsible for the audio-visual aspects of the visit and limits their  responsibility to the personal data related to the registration as indicated on the consent form.

question_text: A local elementary school teacher was one of the first visitors to Museum4yourSenses and was  inspired to launch some educational materials after the visit. However, the teacher was alarmed to learn that a number of children with special needs had their introductory videos selected to promote a diversity and inclusion angle in the promotional materials. What would be her best option to protect childrens rights?
option_a: Send a registered letter to the museum requesting the museum deidentify the personal data to  prevent processing personal data without a legal basis, especially of a vulnerable population and for commercial gain.
option_b: Send a registered letter to the Museum4yourSenses board members, which includes a member  of the EU Directorate General for Education, instructing them to immediately cease processing a vulnerable populations personal data.
option_c: Submit a complaint with the supervisory authority requesting that Museum4yourSenses  restrict processing, citing the large number of children and sensitive data elements that were being processed.
option_d: Email the Museum4yourSenses administration alerting them to her concerns, citing the fact  that childrens personal data was being used without proper consent (of parents or authorised guardians) and therefore, the museum was relying on invalid consent to use this information and should immediately cease processing.

question_text: A company is hesitating between binding corporate rules and standard contractual clauses as a  global data transfer solution. Which of the following statements would help the company make an effective decision?
option_a: Binding corporate rules are especially recommended for small and medium-sized companies.
option_b: The data exporter does not need to be located in the EU for standard contractual clauses to be  valid.
option_c: Binding corporate rules provide a global solution for all the entities of a company that are  bound by the intra-group agreement.
option_d: The company will need the prior authorisation of all EU data protection authorities for  concluding standard contractual clauses.

question_text: Which of the following is NOT a common service model of cloud computing?
option_a: Platform as a Service (PaaS).
option_b: Software as a Service (SaaS).
option_c: Everything as a Service (EaaS).
option_d: Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS).

question_text: You accidently send an email that contains a small amount of personal data, and no sensitive data,  concerning 25 individuals from the EU to the wrong email address. You immediately request the recipient delete the email and the recipient confirms they have done so. After reporting what has happened to your DPO, you take some refresher privacy training for good measure. Under the GDPR, why is it unlikely that your company would be fined as a result of this data breach?
option_a: There was no notification made to the DPA.
option_b: There was no sensitive data involved in the breach.
option_c: The company took all necessary steps to mitigate this breach.
option_d: There are no fines for breaches involving fewer than 50 individuals.

question_text: What is the core concept underpinning the GDPR accountability requirement?
option_a: The obligations with which an organisation must comply to demonstrate and show evidence of  their compliance.
option_b: The internal allocation of privacy responsibilities to show appropriate assignments have been  made.
option_c: The obligation for controllers to provide data subjects with information about the processing of  their personal data.
option_d: The development of internal policies that outline how data should be processed and handled  across the organisation.

question_text: What should an organisation consider when determining appropriate periods for retaining personal  data?
option_a: Whether the stated purpose for collecting the personal data still applies.
option_b: Whether the personal data is stored on premise or with a cloud storage provider.
option_c: Whether the personal data can be retained for an undetermined future use.
option_d: Whether there was a lawful basis for processing when the personal data was collected.

question_text: When is a data sharing agreement most likely to be needed?
option_a: When personal data is being proactively shared by a controller to support a police  investigation.
option_b: When personal data is being shared between commercial organisations acting as joint data  controllers.
option_c: When anonymised data is being shared between a controller and a processor for analytical  purposes.
option_d: When personal data is being shared with a public authority with powers to require the personal  data to be disclosed.

question_text: Which treaty created the European Union?
option_a: 1951 Treaty Establishing the European Coal and Steel community.
option_b: 1957 Treaty Establishing the European Economic Community.
option_c: 1992 Maastricht Treaty.
option_d: 2007 Lisbon Treaty.

question_text: If a multi-national company wanted to conduct background checks on all current and potential  European-based employees, what key provision would the company have to follow?
option_a: Background checks on European employees are regulated under the GDPR and employers  must comply with the guidance therein.
option_b: Background checks on European employees can be performed only after receiving explicit  consent from all employees based in Europe.
option_c: Background checks on European employees will be regulated by data protection and  employment laws in the appropriate member state.
option_d: Background checks on European employees are not allowed, but the company can create a list  of ineligible individuals based on its legitimate interests.

question_text: What is a layered fair processing notice?
option_a: A notice that provides the data subject with information about the purposes of processing a  specific item of personal data.
option_b: A notice that contains the controllers and processors contact information and links to different  topics within the notice.
option_c: A notice no longer than a certain number of words, listing key rights and using bullet points  linked to more detailed information.
option_d: A notice wherein the key information is presented initially, and more detailed information is  made available on a secondary page.

scenario_text:
Please use the following scenario to answer the next THREE questions. 
Excited to go on holiday, Isabelle took a trip to Amsterdam and went on a series of canal tours 
promoted by Novatours, a new Amsterdam-based company. She downloaded the Novatours app on 
her smartphone, accepted the privacy conditions, and connected her credit card for ease of payment. 
Upon return to her residence in France, she received frequent flyers from Novatours and third-party 
vendors. The number of flyers and vendors involved increased over time, including not only tourist 
activities, but also hotels, restaurants, car rentals, museum events, etc. All flyers mentioned a 
partnership with Novatours. 
A few weeks later, she moved to a new apartment. She tried to contact Novatours but she could not 
get past the automated telephone system or the no-reply general email on their website. Isabelle 
concluded there was no way to contact them other than through an affiliated tourist office where she 
first learned about the company.
question_text: Isabelle wants to update her address and limit the sharing of her personal data. What should she  do?
option_a: Send a registered letter to the tourist information centre where she learned about Novatours,  demanding her address be corrected and opting out of data sharing.
option_b: File a complaint with her local supervisory authority stating she cannot reach Novatours  directly and ask them to demand that Novatours and its partners stop processing her personal data.
option_c: Send an email to the Dutch Tourist Authority via their website requesting they mandate  Novatours to update her address and demand they stop sharing her address with other vendors.
option_d: File an official complaint with her local communitys civil population division for protection of  her private information and reference the file number in a demand letter to Novatours to restrict processing.

question_text: Novatours received several similar complaints resulting in the suspension of their licence to  operate. When Novatours lawyer filed a complaint against the supervisory authorities, they were informed that Novatours, as a controller, was legally required to do which of the following?
option_a: Respond within 30 days of receipt of the request.
option_b: Provide contact details of the data protection officer.
option_c: Provide an attestation with the date the personal data has been deleted.
option_d: Honour all data subject requests cited with clear and compelling examples.

question_text: An unforeseen power outage results in Company Z's lack of access to customer data for six hours,  which is considered a breach under Article 32 of the GDPR. Based on the WP29's February 2018 Guidelines on Personal data breach notification (later adopted by the EDPB), Company Z should do which of the following?
option_a: Conduct a thorough audit of all security systems.
option_b: Notify affected individuals that their data was unavailable.
option_c: Notify the supervisory authority about the loss of availability.
option_d: Document the loss of availability to demonstrate accountability.

question_text: Which instrument could be used, or which treaty could be joined, by a non-European country that  wanted to demonstrate an international commitment to implement data protection legislation and to provide protection of individuals with regard to automatic processing of personal data?
option_a: Directive 95/46/EC.
option_b: The Treaty of Lisbon.
option_c: The Council of Europes Convention 108.
option_d: Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.

question_text: In what stages of the project life cycle should data protection by design (also known as privacy by  design) be applied?
option_a: During the entire project life cycle.
option_b: After the development but prior to launch.
option_c: Only during the initiation and planning stages.
option_d: Continually after the project is productionised.

question_text: A data subject makes a subject access request (SAR) to an online retail company for their  personal data. The data subject states that they are making a SAR in accordance with the GDPR; however, if the company credits the data subjects online account with a specified sum of money, the data subject will withdraw their request. The company has not had any previous access requests by other individuals. Which of the following would be legitimate grounds for the company to refuse to comply with the access request?
option_a: The request is manifestly unfounded or excessive.
option_b: The request is frivolous and will be time consuming.
option_c: No other individual has made a similar request for access.
option_d: The company has a policy in place rejecting all access requests.

question_text: Under the GDPR, which of the following is TRUE about data subjects options to exercise their  rights in cases of noncompliance?
option_a: Individuals need to choose whether to take their complaints about noncompliance to DPAs or  to the courts, as they cannot do both simultaneously.
option_b: Individuals can only seek administrative or judicial remedies to noncompliance once they have  made prior complaints to the controller or processor.
option_c: Individuals can take their complaints to DPAs and/or to the courts, regardless of whether they  made prior complaints to the controller or processor.
option_d: Individuals can only take their complaints about noncompliance to the courts via class actions,  whereby a group of individuals are represented as a collective before the courts.

question_text: Which statement about automated decision-making under Article 22 of the GDPR is TRUE?
option_a: Automated decision-making that would otherwise be prohibited is allowed if it is authorised by  law.
option_b: Data subjects must notify controllers that they do not want to be subject to automated  decision-making.
option_c: The right to object to automated decision-making is triggered any time decisions are made by  automated processes.
option_d: Automated decision-making is permitted provided it is first reviewed by a person that cannot  influence the outcome.

question_text: Under the ePrivacy Directive, when a company decides to send direct email marketing, which of  the following legal bases may it generally rely on?
option_a: Consent and legitimate interest.
option_b: Consent and performance of a contract.
option_c: Public interest and compliance with a legal obligation.
option_d: Legitimate interest, consent and performance of a contract.

question_text: A data subject wants to lodge a complaint against a controller about the processing of their data.  Which of the following is NOT a true statement?
option_a: Data subjects are entitled to know about the risk of security breaches involving their personal  data.
option_b: Data subjects have broad rights of recovery and can even recover for nonmaterial damage  and/or distress.
option_c: Data subjects can lodge a complaint with a DPA or the courts without complaining to the  applicable controller first.
option_d: Where multiple parties are involved, any individual controller or processor involved is liable for  the full amount of the damage.

question_text: A company is under investigation by multiple regulators in different countries jurisdictions for not  complying with GDPR fair notice requirements. Which is TRUE of the fines that may be assessed against the company?
option_a: A company can only be fined by one member state even if it has breached the GDPR in several  jurisdictions.
option_b: The criteria of whether and to what extent fines may be imposed can vary depending on the  member state, which would affect the total fines to be imposed.
option_c: The combined fines for all violations cannot exceed 10 million or 2% of the total worldwide  annual turnover of the preceding fiscal year.
option_d: The criteria for what constitutes a breach of the GDPR is different in each member state, which  would affect the total fines to be imposed.

question_text: An employee of company XYZ has just noticed a memory stick containing records of client data,  including their names, addresses and full contact details, has disappeared. The data on the stick is unencrypted and in clear text. It is uncertain what has happened to the stick at this stage, but it likely was lost during the travel of an employee. What should the company do?
option_a: Notify the data protection supervisory authority as soon as possible that a data breach may  have taken place.
option_b: Immediately notify all customers of the company that their information has been accessed by  an unauthorised person.
option_c: Launch an investigation and if nothing is found within one month, notify the data protection  supervisory authority.
option_d: Invoke the disproportionate effort exception to postpone notifying data subjects until more  information can be gathered.

Please use the following scenario to answer the next TWO questions. 
Luca is the owner of a chain of Italian restaurants across Europe. The restaurant has been successful 
but beginning with the COVID pandemic customers have mainly ordered food to pick up and eat at 
home. Luca decided to create a mobile app that allows customers to order ahead and schedule pickup 
times to help alleviate wait times. This also allowed him to build analytics to better staff his 
restaurants in this new era of takeout.
question_text: To comply with the obligations under Article 25 (data protection by design and by default), what  should Luca consider when reviewing and assessing the processing and storage of personal data gathered by his app?
option_a: How many customers will use the application during a specific time frame.
option_b: How the data can be used to create advertisements for further monetisation.
option_c: How to create a shared responsibility matrix so all staff members are aware of privacy  requirements.
option_d: What is the least amount of personal data necessary to run the app and provide the scheduled  pickup time.

option_a: Scope, individual rights and employee responsibilities.
option_b: Policy statement, policy compliance and transparency.
option_c: Scope, reporting incidents and employee responsibilities.
option_d: Policy statement, policy compliance and individual rights.

question_text: Which of the following is a legally binding instrument?
option_a: The UN Universal Declaration of Human Rights.
option_b: The Asian-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) Privacy Framework.
option_c: The OECD Guidelines on the Protection of Privacy and Transborder Flows of Personal Data  (OECD Guidelines).
option_d: The Council of Europe Convention for the Protection of Individuals with regard to Automatic  Processing of Personal Data (Convention 108).

question_text: A U.S.-based pharmaceutical company, Pharma, receives pseudonymised patient information from  clinical sites all over the world, including the EU, as part of a clinical trial. How must Pharma process the data?
option_a: Pharma must de-pseudonymise all data they receive before it can be processed under any  jurisdiction.
option_b: Pharma can process the data as is because it is part of a clinical trial and will be processed only  in the U.S.
option_c: Pharma must comply with all applicable privacy laws based on the country where the data  subject resides.
option_d: Pharma need only comply with the privacy laws concerning data processing that are in effect in  the U.S. and the GDPR.

question_text: Which treaty was issued as a result of the enlargement of the European Community and the  corresponding need to improve the efficiency and speed of decision-making processes?
option_a: The Treaty of Ghent.
option_b: The Treaty of Lisbon.
option_c: The Treaty of Lepanto.
option_d: The Treaty of the Hague.

question_text: When a situation arises in which neither an adequacy decision nor appropriate safeguards are in  place, the GDPR sets forth specific derogations to allow data transfers. Which of the following is a requirement to transfer data under the derogations?
option_a: The transfer is done after suitable safeguards are in place.
option_b: The transfer concerns an unlimited number of data subjects.
option_c: The transfer is necessary for the purpose of direct marketing.
option_d: The transfer is done under the guidance of a data protection officer.

question_text: In which of the following situations must a data protection impact assessment (DPIA) be used?
option_a: A clothing store wants to build aggregated metrics on the types of clothing their customers  purchase by season.
option_b: A start-up company specialising in online gaming is using new technologies to build a new  battleship game.
option_c: A bank is implementing surveillance cameras outside each of their buildings to help them  identify possible bank thieves.
option_d: A pool company is implementing a new advertising campaign targeted to customers who have  visited their store in the past 12 months.

question_text: Which of the following processing conditions would prohibit an organisation from retaining  personal data collected for conducting a webinar once the webinar has concluded and the processing purpose has expired?
option_a: The data will be processed solely for archiving purposes in the public interest.
option_b: The data will be processed for historical research or statistical purposes.
option_c: The data is anonymised and then used for a participant demographics database.
option_d: The data is processed to maintain a CRM database of webinar attendees.

question_text: A grocery store opened on a street that has had regular problems with thefts. Since the grocery  store is new, they do not yet have the budget for a real surveillance system. Instead, they install fake video surveillance cameras to stop potential thieves until they can afford a real surveillance system. The cameras are pointed only inside the store and there are no cameras facing the street. Which GDPR lawful basis is the grocery store most likely to have relied on for the placing of the cameras?
option_a: Consent.
option_b: Legitimate interest.
option_c: The GDPR does not apply.
option_d: Performance of a contract.

question_text: Under what circumstances would the GDPR apply to personal data that exists in physical form,  such as information contained in notebooks or hard copy files?
option_a: Only where the personal data is handled in a sufficiently structured manner to form part of a  filing system.
option_b: Only where the personal data is treated by automated means in some way, such as  computerised sorting, distributing or filing.
option_c: Only where the personal data is subjected to specific computerised processing, such as image  scanning or optical character recognition.
option_d: Only where the personal data is produced as a physical output of specific automated  processing activities, such as printing, labelling or stamping.

question_text: The European Commission has the power to determine whether a country outside of the EU  provides an adequate level of data protection in accordance with the GDPR. Which one of the following countries has been deemed adequate?
option_a: Mexico.
option_b: Nigeria.
option_c: Uruguay.
